Cartan Group was elected by the Ape community to manage governance and voting processes for Ape Improvement Proposals (AIPs). Over 8 months, they've engaged with thousands of community members, expanded their initial scope, and delivered on various tasks. The cost for the expanded scope is proposed at $250,000 USD per month plus 20,000 ApeCoins. This proposal can be found at [AIP-183 link]. The implementation of this AIP is administered by the Ape Foundation, with any significant deviations disclosed to the community.

The proposal suggests allocating $20k per month for bounties to enhance integration between the DAO and core team. The funds will be managed by the leads, initially facilitated by the DAO Ops team. Bounties should follow a SMART deliverables framework and can reach up to $3000 each. The goal is to complete 15 bounties per month with one report highlighting completed work monthly. This initiative aims to increase work completion, improve information flow between teams, and align core team efforts with the DAO, while potential risks include inadequate bounty completion or incorrect contributor selection. Alex Clay will compile the monthly reports. The total funding request is $60,000 for the remainder of season 1.

The team has completed a technical proof-of-concept application for the SubDAO app project, which boosts their confidence in building resilient frontends using web3 technology. Currently, they are working on designing and developing the Easy Governance Frontend (EGF), expected to launch during pregame. Simultaneously, they are coordinating with other teams to adapt Maker's governance and delegation needs for Endgame.

The team recently held their first offsite of the year, focusing on defining work related to the EGF and SubDAO app. They also met with various stakeholders to discuss the Sagittarius Engine, changes to delegation, and the Easy Governance Frontend (EGF).

Hernando has been working on improving the Governance Portal API and app for better efficiency. However, the updates will be deployed after the Endgame Constitution MIP poll concludes. Due to the controversial nature of the poll, additional security measures have been implemented to protect the Governance Portal from potential attacks and keep it running smoothly during traffic peaks.

The team is also preparing documentation on how to manually vote using Etherscan in case the Governance Portal becomes temporarily unavailable. They encourage reporting any issues through a new channel on the MakerDAO Discord server called 'voting-support'.

Lastly, Philip has returned from paternal leave and is now a proud father of a healthy newborn. The team feels good about their current progress and is looking forward to collaborating with other protocol/tooling teams.

The text discusses plans to onboard up to 4 Centrifuge-based collateral by June 11th and introduces a standardized Trust model. The proposed structure involves managing assets through a Delaware Trust or Collateral Agent, with the Cayman Islands handling money flow due to tax issues. A Trust Sponsor is responsible for decision-making, but this role comes with risks and liability concerns.

Two approaches are being considered for decision-making: predefined actions triggered by one or two Maker Representatives, or judgment calls in complex situations. The Maker Representatives would serve on the Cayman Orphan SPV and/or the Wyoming DAO but would not have direct access to funds.

A Verification Agent or Wyoming DAO may enable modification from MakerDAO Governance, while the Wyoming DAO is intended for significant design changes or winding up an investment. The text mentions hiring a Cayman law firm and anticipates additional expenses, with the Wyoming DAO part coming at a later stage.

The forum has been updated for better accessibility. Groups now list Core Unit descriptions, relevant links, and team members. Titles have been added to facilitate identification of Core Unit Facilitators and contributors. These titles are clickable for more information. Additionally, teams can be tagged using @ followed by the team name. Users are encouraged to use these tags responsibly. The Group Pages are useful for learning about Core Units.

The summary for the period April-June 2022 focuses on the adaptation of a protocol, drafting explanatory documents, implementing Aragon Court within a Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO), product evaluation, and budget requirements for phase 1 at $45,000. The budget does not include marketing campaigns or promotional activities, nor the implementation of Phase 3.

The team consists of four members: @eaglelex, a law professor and lawyer with expertise in Blockchain technology, Cryptocurrencies, and DAO regulations; @sabinachain, a legal-tech researcher with experience in US and EU jurisdictions; @lion917, a legal consultant specializing in Asian jurisdictions with expertise in Blockchain, Data Protection, and information technology; and @Tayy, the community lead at Aragon DAO with 2 years of experience in web 3.0.

The payment structure is set to be 50% USDC and 50% ANT, with installments after reaching certain milestones: End of Month 1 (Survey Result, Preliminary Research, and preparation of the workshop - $15k USD), End of Month 2 (Template of Report, Use case Research - $15k USD), and End of Month 3 (Final Report: Analysis and Exact suggestions for phase 2 - $15k USD). An escrow account is not required as the team will be paid through installments.

Polygon has endorsed the deployment of a dispute resolution system internal to DAOs, potentially offering a grant for the development work in the range of $50-70K USD. The new Aragon Court product may also be requested for implementation within the myriad of DAOs currently deploying in Polygon's ecosystem.

A user is seeking financial assistance for a 1-month-old daughter's heart operation, requiring $15,000. They have shared their Ethereum and BEP20 wallet address for donations. The individual needs immediate funds as they must pay the hospital within a week.

The "Committee Formation Proposal" is open for voting in Special Voting Cycle #5, categorized under "Tooling & Infrastructure." Up to 4 committees will be approved for Season 2 based on votes. To promote diversity, the Optimism Foundation suggests delegates vote 'yes' for their top 1-2 committees per category. For more information, visit the Governance Committees introduction at gov.optimism.io/t/introducing-governance-committees/.

The TechOps Core Unit continues to maintain the stability and operability of critical Maker infrastructure on a 24/7 schedule. In February 2023, there were 89 incidents reported across various services such as AWS infrastructure, EC2, MongoDB, Nodes, and Analytics Dashboard. The team also collaborated with internal and external communities to address issues like forum functionality, GitHub authorizations, and Discord user roles. Future plans include improving forum high availability, updating the governance portal API calls, and enhancing security for the governance portal. Regular open office hours are held every last Friday at 14:30 UTC for the Maker Community.

The Davos Protocol aims to increase its presence in both the Balancer and Ethereum ecosystems by introducing a gauge for the new sDAI/DUSD liquidity pool. This move intends to make the pool the primary DUSD liquidity source on Ethereum, while simultaneously boosting DUSD liquidity on Balancer. The Davos Protocol is a decentralized stablecoin protocol operating across various networks, governed by the Davos Governance Token (DGT). It allows users to optimize their crypto assets by accessing loans in DUSD and earning competitive interest rates. The protocol prioritizes Liquid Staking Tokens as collateral and other reward-bearing tokens, enabling compounded yields and DeFi composability. The Davos Protocol redistributes DUSD yield and incentives to stakers, lenders, and liquidity providers. Governance of the protocol is facilitated through DGT, ensuring democratic decision-making, with changes approved by voters not taking effect immediately. The pool is intended to be the primary source of liquidity for the token.

Yesterday, the user's Aave tokens were hacked, with no response from admin yet. They are in contact with support while discussing a way to prevent the thief from accessing approximately 6k still-in-cooldown stkAAVE. The hacker only took a small fraction of the user's total funds, suggesting that they had access only to Aave and Eth funds. The user has emptied their funds after the incident. They believe that anyone who has given permission to Aave.com is at risk of losing their Aave and Eth. To prevent further loss, the user proposes extending the cooldown time of the stolen stkAAVE until investigation concludes. They are willing to donate half of the stolen Aave funds to the community or freeze them permanently. They seek advice on the best course of action, with 7 days left before the hacker can cash the fund.

Title: Onboarding sDAI as a Collateral-Only Asset in Aave V3 Ethereum Pool

Author: Marc Zeller (Aave Chan Initiative, Chaos Labs)

Date: 2023-08-09

Summary: Proposal to integrate sDAI into the Aave V3 Ethereum pool as a collateral-only asset. This move aims to create new synergies with MakerDAO ecosystem and offer users dual benefits of earning DSR yield while utilizing assets as collateral. The proposal does not conflict with the DSR integration in aDAI reserve proposal, but rather complements it. Changes in parameters for Aave V3 & V2 Ethereum pools are proposed, including adjustments to wETH Optimal Ratio, RF, and LTV/LT/Liquidation penalty for sDAI and DAI. If approved, both sDAI and DAI would serve as reserves in the Aave V3 Ethereum pool. The Aave-Chan Initiative & Chaos Labs are not affiliated with or paid by MakerDAO to publish this proposal.

This Temp Check proposes adding slisBNB from ListaDAO to Aave V3 BNB chain. The motivation includes enhancing LST liquidity, asset diversity, and providing opportunities for both communities to earn passive yields and a Lista token airdrop. If approved, the proposal will progress through various stages, culminating in an AIP vote for final confirmation. The proposal is not directly affiliated with Lista DAO, and no compensation was received for its creation.

The text discusses a proposal to integrate Balancer token into the Infinity Wallet and website, offering BAL tokens to Infinity Wallet users via giveaways or airdrops. The Infinity Wallet is a multi-asset decentralized finance wallet with features such as user account management, connection to DeFi platforms, portfolio tracking, one-click swapping, news updates, market monitoring, alerts, and more. The integration aims to expand the community, provide self-custodial storage for BAL, and enhance user experience by allowing easy sending, receiving, and exchanging of BAL within the wallet. This is planned for September 2020, with a grant amount of 600 BAL vesting. The Infinity Wallet is a leading all-in-one decentralized financial application designed for ease of use and security.
Message suggests increasing lottery allocation to 12% may boost interest. Remaining burn pool at 28%.

The proposal aims to expand the eligible tokens for the exchange gas reimbursement pilot, currently running for two more weeks, to include all whitelisted tokens used in BAL liquidity mining. This change will take effect from February 8 and up to 7,500 BAL will be allocated weekly for gas cost reimbursement of swaps performed through the Balancer Exchange Proxy. The expansion is intended to increase decentralization by distributing BAL tokens to more Balancer users, both liquidity providers and traders. The mechanics remain the same as the original proposal, with eligible swaps limited to transactions between an EOA account and the Balancer Exchange Proxy, a maximum gas reimbursement of 100,000 units per swap, and reimbursements made in BAL, not ETH. If the number of tokens to be distributed exceeds the budget, all reimbursements will be scaled down proportionally. The proposal also includes an amendment to filter out any detected gaming or wash trading from the distribution.
This subcategory holds Signal Requests, either accepted or declined.
This category encompasses diverse discussion threads, not fitting under other defined categories.

The user is having trouble testing the supply function in Compound V3 (Comet) using Foundry. They have tested with Hardhat and it worked, but not with Foundry. The user's code involves a contract named ContractTest, which interacts with Comet and USDC tokens. The user sets up the test environment by creating a fork, pranking an address to simulate the top holder of USDC, and approving the Comet contract for token transfers. However, despite rolling to a new block, the balance of the Comet contract does not change as expected after executing the supply function. The user is seeking assistance or solutions for this issue.
The Governance Fund Phase 1 proposal is now eligible for voting in Cycle 4. It has been approved as ready for vote by a delegate. For more information, visit the Voting Cycle 4 Roundup.

The text discusses a STIP (Snapshot Improvement Proposal) application by L2BEAT, requesting 500,000 ARB. The proposal was further detailed in an addendum. The proposal warrants closer attention due to the provided addendum.

On March 14th, Tool House Rock is hosting Common Ground founders and designers to discuss their solution for a unified web3 platform for community interaction. The focus is on addressing the challenge of communication within Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs). Common Ground offers an all-in-one platform with features like end-to-end encrypted DMs, voice chats, layer 2 token-gating, and community growth tracking. The session will include a product demonstration, Q&A, and relevance discussion with Endgame. The event will be hosted by @Retro and @Juan on Zoom. If you can't attend, post your questions here for the hosts to ask during the Q&A.

The Real-World Finance Core Unit's strategy involves onboarding $300M of real-world assets, partnering with Centrifuge for smart contract investments in structured finance and exploring a Trust-based method using MakerDAO balance sheet. They aim to build a strong capital base and inform the market about MakerDAO's financial strength.

Highlights include successful onboarding of New Silver ($588k loans), preparation for more Centrifuge-related RWA onboarding, progress in Trust-related RWA using MIP21, and a proposed framework for valuing MKR. Legal advisors are being onboarded, research is ongoing regarding crypto banking, clearinghouse systems, and DeFi, and marketing efforts have led to media coverage.

The team consists of SebVentures (facilitator), Williamr, Philinje, Jameskmccall, Christiancdpetersen, and Aes. The budget for the Core Unit is managed through a multisig wallet. Previous reports include March 2021, February 2021, and January 2021.

The proposal is for a gauge for inswETH/swETH on Ethereum, submitted by InceptionLRT. InceptionLRT is an isolated Liquid Restaking protocol for Liquid Staking Tokens (LSTs). Its core feature is the issuance of Isolated Liquid Restaking Tokens (iLRTs) for each restaked LST, which can be traded and used in DeFi. The aim is to enhance liquidity and utility of inswETH, enabling its integration into various DeFi protocols.

Governance is handled by ING holders who participate in decision-making, influencing the protocol's direction and policies. Incentive allocation is done through gauge weight voting, directing incentives towards preferred liquidity. Rewards are earned by providing ING to liquidity pools like Balancer Liquidity Pools and locking the LP token earns veING.

InceptionLRT undergoes security audits, with the latest audit by Veridise. It is designed to bolster the EigenLayer framework, addressing the issue of liquidity locking in the protocol. InceptionLRT aims to be a key player in enhancing the fluidity and accessibility of restaking in the DeFi landscape.

Further details can be found on their website, documentation, GitHub page, and communities on Twitter and Discord.

Securitize, a leading digital asset securities company, is a FINRA member Broker-Dealer and SEC-registered Transfer Agent with extensive compliance services for digital assets companies. Its proprietary investor passport, Securitize iD, is globally recognized and trusted by over 400K registered investors and more than 200 issuers. Backed by top investors from traditional and digital finance, Securitize aims to unite stakeholders in both sectors. It seeks the Aave Governance community's appointment as a whitelister for Aave Arc deployments due to its highly regulated status, existing KYC/KYB/AML/CFT services, blockchain-based Securitize iD, and fulfillment of whitelister requirements set forth in the Aave Arc white paper.

The text discusses an update to a proposal regarding the deployment of a new DAO, Delegate Voting DAO, which will replace the current AN DAO. This new DAO will support delegated voting and will transfer the Aragon Project Funds. The main point of discussion is what happens to the AN DAO when the new Delegate Voting DAO is deployed. There are three elements of the AN DAO: Governance, Finance, and Community. The governance question will be addressed in this proposal, while finance and community questions will be addressed in separate proposals. The Delegate Voting DAO will enact a new Charter on-chain to prepare for the treasury transfer. ANT Holders will decide whether they want to uphold or terminate the AN DAO Charter when the Charter of the Delegate Voting DAO is enacted. If the result is "Yes", the AN DAO Charter termination timing will be either 15 or 30 days after the Delectorate Voting DAO Charter is enacted. The financial risks of terminating the AN DAO Charter are addressed in a separate Financial Proposal. Both proposals will be put to vote on Aragon Voice at the same time for cross-referencing.

The text discusses a proposal for a minimum holding requirement for individuals making grant requests in ApeCoin DAO. The aim is to reduce excessive grant requests, limit grift, and reserve significant grants for committed community members. This could preserve the value of APE within the ecosystem and foster deeper alignment among community members. No cost is associated with this proposal. The Facilitator team will assist in the process, and the discussion period can be extended if needed.

The text outlines the governance structure for a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO). It details the roles and responsibilities of domain teams (Risk-Core-Unit, Smart Contracts, Oracles) and Governance Facilitators in triggering emergency polls or executives based on potential risks to the protocol. The community can also propose changes, but they must meet certain requirements for a majority vote and quorum to be enacted. The Maker Foundation may intervene in extreme situations, but it's encouraged to avoid such instances as they indicate a failure of the DAO to handle critical issues independently.

The Balancer Grant program, part of the Balancer DAO, supports projects building on the Balancer Protocol. Wave 13 of this program, lasting until September 2024, has a budget of 75k BAL for distribution to grantees. This wave is focused on teams developing on Balancer V3, an improved architecture in development that offers simplified integrations and continued flexibility.

Two grants have been awarded this month: one to QuantAMM for extending their pool simulator to support various Balancer v3 pool types, and another to a long-term partner for bringing their pools to v3. A competition with BAL prizes and access to Balancer developers is planned to foster creative implementations on the new architecture.

The program has approved 2 grants out of 22 applications, totaling 20,000 BAL. Grantees like Eridani (Dynamic Fee Research) and Opal Finance are making progress in their projects. QuantAMM is working on meeting their first milestones for protocol translation with Balancer V3.

The program encourages unique ideas to improve and expand the flexible technology of Balancer, and applications can be submitted through the Grants Application form. For more information about the grants program, visit the grants page or send an email to [grants@balancer.community](mailto:grants@balancer.community).

The text discusses the current high cost of bridging XVS tokens from the Binance Smart Chain (BSC) to the Ethereum chain using Venus, a decentralized finance platform. Currently, only 10,000 XVS can be bridged at once, which costs around 0.35 BNB or approximately $200 per transaction. This high cost is a barrier for large token holders, referred to as 'whales', who may not be interested in bridging their bags at this time. The text suggests that Venus should increase the bridge limits or provide an option to withdraw XVS directly into Ethereum to meet the expected demand from potential Prime holders on BSC, which could amount to 60,000 XVS or more needing to be bridged. If not addressed, this could create a significant problem due to insufficient liquidity in Ethereum.
Suggestion made to create a learning section for beginners, appreciating your contribution.
The deadline for reward distribution has been extended, as a new, potentially superior strategy is being considered.

Four proposals have been suggested for the allocation of $300k in unused user funds from an ibBTC multi-sig.

1. Seed Initial eBTC Liquidity: Use the funds to create a tightly bound wBTC/eBTC Uniswap v3 pool, providing initial and perpetual liquidity for eBTC without draining Badger emissions.

2. Extraordinary Bootstrapping Yield for eBTC: Utilize the funds to offer high yield for eBTC liquidity pools during its launch phase.

3. Community Council Controlled Yield Assets: Place the funds under the discretion of the community council, allowing them to invest in various yield-bearing assets and governance tokens over a 6-month period, with 50% of the monthly yield emitted to vault depositors after the initial phase.

4. None of the Above: No specific allocation is chosen, leaving the funds untouched until a new decision is made.

Each option aims to benefit the DAO and its users in different ways, focusing on liquidity provision, high yield generation, or community council control over investments.

The proposal aims to whitelist the DFX Finance Gnosis Safe multisig for vote-locking B-80BAL-20WETH into veBAL, enabling participation in Balancer DAO governance. DFX Finance is a decentralized foreign exchange protocol facilitating stablecoin exchanges across multiple currencies. The proposal highlights the intention to engage with the Balancer ecosystem and incentivize liquidity flow through Balancer. The multisig signers acknowledge the risk associated with vote-locking veBAL, committing not to tokenize it using this safe. If approved, the DFX Finance Gnosis Safe multisig address will be whitelisted to interact with the veBAL contract.

The text discusses a grant proposal by Felix Lutsch to produce a research report comparing various methods for distributing ETH deposited into the Lido protocol across different staking router modules. The report aims to provide a framework for the Lido Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO) to make informed decisions on distribution mechanisms, such as SimpleDVT and Community Staking. The research will take into account discussions with key stakeholders, existing research, and deployed mechanisms in the crypto space. The grant is for 45,000 DAI, with a payment schedule of 30% upfront and 70% upon publication. Felix invites input from Lido DAO contributors for the final report.

The text discusses a proposal to update the distribution of rewards for certain pools in the Balancer ecosystem. This is necessary due to an upgrade in Paladin's questboard contract, which requires a new contract to handle token distribution. The DAO multisig is requested to execute transactions to transfer distributorship on specified gauges to the new Paladin V2 Questboard contract. The affected pools include Balancer DOLA/USDC StablePool, sDOLA Stable Pool, 2BTC, and others. The proposal aims to improve incentives for liquidity provision by Inverse Finance and Threshold through veBAL voting incentives. The multisig will grant itself the ability to call set_reward_distributor on the gauge deployment, update each gauge/token in the list, and then revoke its own rights to call set_reward_distributor.

The proposal is to adjust the start of afterburn based on the Lock time, not a fixed 7 days. For instance, if Staker A locks for 52 weeks, they'll have 52 weeks to move or relock before afterburn begins. Similarly, Staker B, who locks for 12 weeks, will have 12 weeks to move or relock before afterburn starts.

The text proposes a plan to ensure the continued growth and development of Sushiswap, a rapidly evolving industry. The author suggests hiring a top skilled developer as the leader to drive progress. They propose a quantitative evaluation of all community contributors' workloads, including Maki, Chefnomi, SBF, and other developers and operations staff. Salaries should be comparable to those at YFI. After evaluation, suitable leaders for Sushiswap's long-term development should be recommended. A tenure system for leaders is also proposed, lasting one year or more. The goal is to secure Sushiswap's future and encourage progress rather than stagnation.

Title: Whitelist AURA/ETH Pool on Balancer

Description: The text discusses the whitelisting of a new AURA/ETH pool on the Balancer platform. This move is aimed at boosting liquidity for AURA and supporting its successful launch. The pool is located at https://app.balancer.fi/#/pool/0xc29562b045d80fd77c69bec09541f5c16fe20d9d000200000000000000000251.

References: The text provides links to the Aura Finance website, documentation, GitHub page, Discord community, and forum.

Protocol Description: Aura Finance is a platform that coordinates incentives around vote-escrowed tokens to boost yield potential and governance power in DeFi. It leverages veBAL from Balancer Labs.

Motivation: The synergies between Balancer and Aura are highlighted, with the approval of this gauge for the 80/20 AURA/ETH pool expected to support a successful launch period and provide deep liquidity for AURA.

Specifications:
- Governance: Aura's governance structure is managed by treasury and protocol multisigs, with details provided on their respective addresses.
- Oracles: The protocol does not rely on external oracles.
- Audits: Audit reports can be found at https://docs.aura.finance/aura/security#audits.
- Centralization vectors: Aura is a non-custodial, non-pausable platform with no identified centralization vectors.
- Market History: The LBP (Liquidity Bootstrapping Pool) can be accessed at https://app.aura.finance/. The gauge address is located at https://etherscan.io/address/0x006aad228d44655c4c97cdda600f2d56e99569b9.

The Tribe DAO applied for veBAL allowlisting last month, which was granted. They successfully locked 112,041 B-80BAL-20WETH tokens into veBAL. The DAO also owns B-70WETH-30FEI BPTs and staked them in the gauge to earn BAL for around 3 weeks. However, they discovered an issue where their contract could not claim BAL rewards associated with gauge staking. After discussion with Balancer team, it was identified that BAL is distributed through a BalancerMinter contract connected to the gauge system, but the Tribe devs mistakenly used contracts from Angle Protocol which distribute ANGLE differently. As a result, 34,344 BAL tokens farmed by the Tribe DAO are unclaimable on the BalancerMinter. The Tribe DAO is requesting the Balancer DAO to OTC these BAL tokens back to them and has deployed a new gauge staking contract shortly.
The text suggests a question about suicide, either affirmative or negative. It does not provide an answer.
The initial migration is a significant achievement for the project, requiring full commitment from the involved party. Offering a grant could motivate the individual.
Twitter Space "Beam" was discontinued, with no recent updates on further beam developments. The related news has become relatively quiet.

The upcoming release of Aragon Govern allows communities without ERC20 tokens to easily create their own token and establish a governance structure within minutes. This can be done through the Aragon Client. Vocdoni, previously thought to be for communities without ERC20 tokens, is now integrated into Aragon Voice. Proposals can be published quickly by anyone in these communities, but they are not yet fully integrated into Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs).

This document outlines a proposal for an incentivization program on the Arbitrum Network. The program aims to support protocols that are live on Arbitrum and have not farmed their own incentive programs. To be eligible, grantees must outline a spending plan, provide data on distributions, transactions, TVL, unique addresses, transaction fees, and contract addresses being used for incentive rewards. They must also agree to KYC with the Arbitrum Foundation and disclose contracts being incentivized.

The multisig will be empowered to halt fund streaming in case of negligence or misuse of funds, such as using funds not explicitly described in the grantee's application or failure to comply with data reporting standards. Grantees must apply using an approved program application template and provide Dune dashboards for 30 days before, during, and after the Incentivization period.

The total cost of the program is 35,665,000 ARB, distributed as follows:
- Incentives: 35,000,000 ARB
- Council Members: 125,000 ARB (25,000 ARB each)
- Application Advisors: 70,000 ARB (35,000 ARB each)
- Research Bounties: 200,000 ARB Total
- Data and Analytics Provider: 150,000 ARB for data monitoring and reporting
- Program Manager: 100,000 ARB for program design, organization, management, research report, and continuing development of the Long Term Incentives Framework.
- Multisig Signers: 20,000 ARB (2,500 ARB each)

The proposal is experimental in nature, with the multisig empowered to halt streaming only in case of negligence or misuse of funds, not for quality control on the design of incentive programs. The process includes a snapshot vote, KYC for grantees, application feedback, grant agreement signing, data reporting, and funding initiation. Research bounties will be selected and completed throughout the process.

The text discusses a STIP (Scale the Impact Program) application by Cattin - Seed Latam, proposing 2.25M ARB. The request warrants closer attention due to an addendum provided. The initial application can be found on Arbitrum's forum.
The initial migration is a significant achievement requiring full commitment. A grant could serve as an effective incentive for this undertaking.

To achieve this, meme coins like PINK should be available on multiple parachains such as Astar Network. The process involves registering the token from Polkadot Asset Hub and listing it on Astar Portal. More information can be found on their Twitter, Telegram, and game platform.

The text discusses a proposed Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO) designed to facilitate art funding for artists through share token sales. Investors purchase these tokens, which represent shares in an artwork, similar to company stocks. The artist can only access funds once the required amount is fully raised and not refunded if the target isn't met by a specific date. The share token specifies investor rewards. Upon completion of the artwork sale, the artist pays investors directly from their wallets on a specified contract date, and the DAO terminates. The author questions whether Aragon can support these features, including token shares, funding thresholds, automatic refunds if targets aren't met, investment return payments, and DAO termination upon meeting investment returns.

Summary:

The proposal is about deploying Uniswap v3 contracts on the Mantle Network, which will enable liquidity provision and trading of assets on this network. The deployment will be subject to Ethereum Layer 1 governance and control, with the relevant contracts being verified and included in the text record of the uniswap.eth ENS subdomain. The Uniswap contracts are owned by a cross-chain account controlled by the Uniswap DAO on L1 (Ethereum Layer 1). A $250k incentive package for Mantle has already been approved by the DAO. No further steps are needed from the DAO as this deployment is now set in motion.

Key Points:
- Proposer: Mantle Core Contributor Team
- Deployer: GFX Labs
- Bridge Provider: Mantle Native Bridge
- Target Chain: Mantle Network
- Uniswap v3 Contracts have been verified and will be included in the text record of the uniswap.eth ENS subdomain
- The Uniswap contracts are owned by a cross-chain account controlled by the Uniswap DAO on L1
- A $250k incentive package for Mantle has been approved by the DAO, no further steps needed from the DAO.

This proposal aims to activate a 2% capped gauge for an 80% D2D / 20% GYD pool on the Arbitrum Network. The collaboration is between PrimeDAO and Gyroscope, moving liquidity from the ETH Mainnet D2D / USDC pool to a pool using GYD on Arbitrum. This change may increase volumes for both pools.

PrimeDAO is a DAO-builder collective that has launched various products like Prime Rating, Prime Launch, and Inverter Network. It is governed by holders of D2D and pooled D2D through Snapshot Votes and Forum Proposals. The proposal does not use oracles; instead, it uses Coingecko. The Balancer Maxi LM Multisig will interact with the GaugeAdderv4 and call the addGauge function with the specified gauge address (0xBC5E2f2945Ff4a6568C4DBD3aA15D9e8FfDF0125) and gaugeType (Arbitrum).

Title: Introduction to JPYC (JPYCoin), Japan's First Yen Stablecoin

   JPYCoin, the first Japanese Yen Stablecoin, utilizes blockchain technology and maintains a 1:1 parity with the Japanese yen. It operates on multiple networks including Ethereum, Astar, Polygon, Gnosis, and Avalanche. Users can store it in wallets like Metamask or trade it on platforms such as Uniswap.

   The project is compliant with Japan's Payment Act Law. JPYC Inc. is the team behind its development. More information can be found on their website (https://jpyc.jp/).

   Milestones achieved include issuing $10M worth of JPYC across multiple chains, collaborating with DEXs for liquidity mining, and launching farming campaigns on Arthwap, a major DEX on Astar.

   Future plans involve collaboration with DeFi projects on Astar, enabling cross-chain compatibility, going public on the Japanese Tosho Market, and forming partnerships with other stablecoin companies to enhance on/off ramp adoption.

To participate in ApeCoin voting on Snapshot, follow these steps:

1. Access Snapshot site.
2. Connect your digital wallet containing ApeCoins.
3. Authenticate yourself to prove ApeCoin ownership without spending transaction fees.
4. Find the proposal you wish to vote on and vote for or against it. Your vote is proportional to the number of ApeCoins you hold.
5. Each ApeCoin equals one vote in the ApeCoin DAO voting process, allowing democratic participation in decisions concerning the ApeCoin ecosystem.

The post discusses two main issues and proposed solutions within the Starknet decentralized protocol, focusing on forced staking updates and empty blocks.

1. Forced Staking Updates:
   - Problem: Delay in resetting the protocol due to forced staking updates can take more than 24 hours.
   - Solution: Make a proof a "public good" as soon as it is computed, adding it to a common pool of proofs available to all nodes. This avoids issues related to forced staking updates and introduces a new component into the protocol.

2. Empty Blocks:
   - Problem: Proposers can propose empty blocks, which may lead to censoring transactions or damaging the quality of the chain.
   - Solution: Decrease rewards for consecutive empty blocks proposed by the same node, but not for the first time an empty block is proposed. This discourages nodes from proposing (only) empty blocks when not necessary.

The post concludes by inviting feedback on these reflections to improve the robustness of the Starknet protocol.

1. PancakeSwap (PCS) needs to cease promoting Binance Coin (BNB) and focus on Chainlink Coin (CAKE).
   2. PCS should stop limiting itself to one blockchain and adopt a multi-chain approach, as other platforms have.
   3. Improve website speed for better user experience.
   4. PCS needs to acquire part of the liquidity and strengthen its treasury for development purposes.
   5. PCS should increase burns or reduce emissions to combat market saturation with CAKE.
   6. PCS should focus on its core strengths such as Launchpad, Initial Farm Offerings (IFO), farming, etc., rather than pursuing trends like NFTs.
   7. Only farms involving CAKE pairs should pay out in CAKE; other farms should use their native tokens to avoid inflationary pressure and potential high selling pressure from users opting not to choose CAKE.

The document presents a proposal for the distribution of 125,000 $ARB tokens as retroactive rewards to 24 dedicated and earliest contributors to the Arbitrum community, known as Arbiters. These individuals have provided significant service to the Arbitrum community over the past two years.

The proposed distribution method is equal for all 24 arbiters, with each receiving approximately 5,208.333 $ARB tokens. One of the arbiters, Discord ID BILLY#7943, has voluntarily relinquished their award and split it equally amongst the other arbiters, resulting in a change from 25 arbiters to 24.

The Arbitrum DAO will collect wallet addresses through a designated process for reward distribution. If approved, the rewards will be distributed to each Arbitrator Contributor's address after thorough verification and validation.

This proposal is part of an initiative to recognize and appreciate the valuable contributions made by the Arbiters to the community, aiming to revitalize engagement, promote openness, and encourage continued participation. The long-term sustainability of the Arbitrum community is a priority in this effort.

The document also includes lists of partial contributions and individual contribution information for each Arbiter, as well as a detailed description and breakdown of their application for retroactive rewards. These resources are provided to allow DAO delegates to check updates on the Arbiters' contributions.

Lastly, the document encourages feedback and interaction from the community in shaping its future. The goal is to build a more collaborative, innovative, and vibrant Arbitrum community that reflects the values and spirit of the ecosystem.

Lido is seeking input from potential relay providers interested in collaborating with their protocol. The goal is to refine Lido's relay policy through collective discussion with these providers and DAO stakeholders. To mitigate operational risks, a trustworthy list of relays will be established for use by Lido Node Operators. This "must-include list" will consist of vetted, reliable relays. A second, less stringent list called the "allow list" will include approved but less well-known or tested relays. Both lists will be public and editable.

Relays must be publicly available, listed, open source, and transparent about any transaction or address filtering they enforce. Lido is encouraging interested relay providers to express their intent, provide organizational background, explain why their relay should be approved, and contribute to the discussion on Lido's relay policy.

As of February 10, 2023, the relay list is maintained on-chain in a relevant contract. A full list of relay providers and their status can be found on the Relay Maintenance Committee public page. Updates have been made to the Goerli relay details for Eden, Ultrasound.money, and Aestus, with mainnet additions planned once sufficiently tested.

With over $22M in total liquidity on Balancer Pools, Gnosis seeks to strengthen ties with Balancer for the upcoming launch of Gnosis Protocol V2, a Meta Dex-Aggregator. Gnosis currently holds significant BAL tokens, intending to transfer them to GnosisDAO as an investment. GNO is the governance token of GnosisDAO, a rapidly growing Ethereum infrastructure component that owns several core Ethereum components and will soon launch Gnosis Protocol V2.
Discussion about project proposals for 0x Starter Project is ongoing. Proposals are invited for building decentralized exchange solutions on Ethereum blockchain.

The second quarter of 2024 focused on improving core infrastructure for reward distribution and allocation, with significant progress made as outlined in the Q2 funding proposal. Key achievements include:

1. Fee Sweep Automation: A new bal_tools repository was refactored, reducing workload and enabling over $750k in fees to be shipped monthly without major incidents.

2. vlAURA Voting: An automated solution for voting incentives was developed, improving transparency and reducing errors. Automatic relocking of the position is yet to be developed.

3. OZ Defender Migration: The code base was successfully migrated to OZ Defender v2, with improvements in gas usage and upgrades completed.

4. Rewards Injector v2: Smart contract development for the new version has been completed, with integration tests underway. Expected to go live in Q3 2024.

5. Gauges and Core pools: Automatic core pool detection was integrated into the code base, with cross-referencing of YB token requirements and rate provider reviews upcoming.

Additional development work included advising partners on DAO treasury data and maintaining DeFilytica analytics and tooling deployments for Balancer and AURA DAOs. The Maxis dedicated an additional $15,365 discretionary budget to various work packages in June, with savings of $51,000 anticipated for Q3.

Looking ahead, the focus will be on supporting Balancer v3 design, improving partner onboarding guides, setting up a Zen UI beta testing program, and ensuring seamless user experiences while maintaining secure on-chain operations.

This text describes a proposed implementation of Zero Knowledge Governance (ZK Governance) for the Starknet ecosystem, focusing on privacy and anonymity in governance processes. The ZK Governance system includes:

1. Voting Process: After voting ends, coordinators verify and process messages in batches using zk-SNARK proofs to ensure correct decryption and state tree updates without retaining outdated votes. Tallying of votes is done offline with another zk-SNARK proof for transparency.

2. Verification: The verifier contract on Starknet validates the proofs, ensuring the messages were processed correctly.

3. Results Publication: Once all messages are processed and verified, the voting results can be announced, and anyone can verify their accuracy using zk-SNARK proofs. Individual votes remain confidential to protect privacy.

4. Integration with Starknetâs Governance Platform: ZK Governance will be integrated into the existing governance platform to provide a privacy layer, encouraging higher participation rates and improving the quality of decision-making.

5. Key Deliverables: An anonymous forum section and an anti-censorship/anonymous voting mechanism are planned as part of this integration.

6. Benefits for Starknet Ecosystem: Implementing ZK Governance is expected to lead to higher participation rates, stronger community engagement, improved decision-making, enhanced security, and a more vibrant ecosystem overall.

7. References: The proposal references research by Vitalik Buterin, gubsheep, and Sun Yi on minimal anti-collusion infrastructure, ZK Identity, and MACI (Minimal Anti-Collusion Infrastructure).

The text discusses a proposed new syscall, get_class_hash_at or class_hash_syscall, for Starknet's smart contract environment. This syscall aims to retrieve the class hash of a deployed contract at a specific address within the contract execution environment.

Currently, there is no way to perform this operation within the smart contract itself. In contrast, Ethereum and EVM systems store copies of the code multiple times if the same contract is deployed numerous times.

The motivation for this syscall comes from the need to check a contract's class hash, as seen in Kakarot's use of replace_class_hash syscall for upgrades at the contract level and using class hashes as a means of checking contract versions. This syscall would enable contract-level orchestration of versioning and auto-upgrade for Kakarot Account Contracts.

The proposed API for this syscall includes two options: get_class_hash_at_syscall and class_hash_syscall, both returning the ClassHash if the contract is deployed and an error if it is not. The implementation details are yet to be defined by the Starkware team.

The text also mentions that copyright and related rights have been waived via MIT.

The proposal aims to whitelist the COW/GNO pool gauge for veBAL voting, strengthening ties between the COW and BAL communities. The COW Protocol allows users to swap assets at best exchange rates using a batch settlement layer on top of AMMs and DEX aggregators. It uses solvers to settle trades, with CoWs (Coincidence of Wants) leading to lower gas costs, fees, and execution risk. The proposal motivates increased BAL rewards for COW liquidity providers and is governed by COW and vCOW token holders through snapshot votes and forum proposals. No oracles are used in the protocol, and audits have been conducted on the settlement contract and COW token. Decentralization of orderbook and solver competition is planned, with potential risks mainly being censorship of orders. The COW token was made transferable on March 28th and previously had incentives for providing liquidity in Balancer pools.

The Uniswap Delegate Reward has been executed, and rewards will be available starting June 2024. To qualify, delegates must maintain 80% voting participation over the past three months, with a snapshot date on July 1st at 9pm CET. Qualifying delegates will receive $3,000 USD worth of UNI.

Additionally, an extra reward is available if delegates write rationales for their votes and submit them by July 3rd at 9pm CET. Delegates are encouraged to create a delegate profile to share updates and rationales. The Accountability Committee will monitor participation, share status, and announce qualifications by July 8th.

The Uniswap Delegate Reward Working Group is required to fill out hours for retro payment using a provided template by June 10th at 9pm CET. The current working group will be dissolved, and new groups or ideas are welcome for the upcoming Cycle 2.

The text proposes a new achievement record (ATH) for cakes, achieved by halting emissions, using cake for NFT transactions instead of BNB, and enhancing cake's utilities to restore its greatness. It asks the community if they agree to halt emission to make CAKE great again.

The text discusses proposed changes in the governance structure of Balancer. These changes include:

1. Adding a strategy created by Aura team to Balancer's snapshot, allowing vlAURA holders to vote with weight proportional to veBAL held by Aura.
2. Increasing the quorum for voting from 100k veBAL to 200k veBAL, which may be further increased in the future.
3. Reducing the frequency of signing requests and bundling proposals together for simultaneous vote once a week on Thursdays.
4. Transferring control over balancer.eth ENS to the DAO Multisig.
5. Setting snapshot admin to the Emergency subDAO Multisig for future updates.

The risks mentioned are potential delays in time-sensitive proposals due to weekly voting and possible failure to hit the new quorum. An exception will be made for emergency or time-sensitive proposals.

A proposal for a Non-Fungible Token (NFT) that can only be minted using CAKE. The CAKE from the minting process will be burned completely. This NFT can be staked to generate a new token with limited supply, which can also be obtained through NFT staking. The generated tokens and NFTs can be used as in-game characters for the CAKE Play-to-Earn (P2E) or Metaverse platform. This system aims to burn CAKE while rewarding its holders with potential investment growth.

Chaos Labs proposes enhancing the XVS Bridge parameters for increased usage on Ethereum Mainnet, aiming to boost growth due to an upcoming emissions plan. The suggested changes include:

1. MaxDailyLimit increase to $1M, below 10% of the average daily trading volume of XVS over the past year, to minimize extreme liquidity shocks without posing significant financial risks.
2. MaxSingleTransactionLimit increase from $10K to $100,000 to reduce high Ethereum transaction fees and enable more affordable bridging while benefiting from vault emissions on Ethereum.
3. The Mint Limit for XVS on Ethereum Mainnet is currently set at $7.5M but should be revised upward as bridging activity increases, with continuous monitoring of user activity to adjust the limit accordingly.

The text discusses the potential benefits of deploying Uniswap v3 on EVM compatible networks like Arbitrum and Matic. The argument is that being available across multiple networks increases value and adoption, while not doing so allows other exchanges to fill the gap, potentially affecting future fees. Additionally, deployment on these networks could expand the list of projects built on Uniswap v3. The text suggests initiating a discussion for deploying Uniswap v3 on the Arbitrum network immediately, as Arbitrum is set to launch later this week. This can be achieved by opening the Uniswap v3 license and allowing community developers to implement it on Arbitrum.

This text summarizes a plan to create four intellectual property (IP) podcast series and a stand-alone ApeCoin and Web3 chat show, with content produced in Mexico and Honduras. The IPs will be developed over a period of 8 months, starting with pre-production such as script development, casting, and recording planning. Production and post-production will take place over the next 6 months, followed by publishing, marketing, and promotion.

The stand-alone APE and Web3 chat show will be produced over a period of 12 months, starting with concept development and host hiring in the first two months. The production and post-production process will follow, along with publishing, marketing, and promotion.

The total cost for this project is $380,050 USD, with $297,650 USD allocated for the four IPs and $82,400 USD for the stand-alone APE and Web3 chat show. The goal is to push ApeCoin into mainstream culture, generate a significant return on investment (ROI) for the ApeCoin DAO, and raise awareness about wrongful convictions through one of the IPs titled "Guilty Until Proven."

The project aims to unlock new niches by focusing on mass-consumption content in multiple languages. Additionally, there is a possibility of developing blockchain technologies to fund and create content IPs with transparency and mutually beneficial outcomes in the future.

The authors propose using the research bounty section in LTIPP (Liquidity Token Incentive Program Participation Pool) to compare various programs and create Key Performance Indicators (KPIs). They categorize questions into five main areas: User Acquisition, Liquidity Acquisition, Volume/ Sequencer fees, Innovation of protocols, and Liquidity for $ARB. Each category has specific questions aimed at understanding user behavior, liquidity acquisition efficiency, volume generated, innovation uniqueness, and ARB token liquidity. The authors suggest allocating $ARB to each category to allow different service providers to focus on their areas of expertise. They also emphasize the need for continuous research funding and a reviewal process to ensure success.

The Uniswap Accountability Committee is proposing to gain multisig agency over the v3-deployments.uniswap.eth and v2deployments.uniswap.eth subdomains. This will allow them to update these text records whenever a new deployment is complete without an onchain vote. The DAO can still assign incentive distributions from the treasury to these deployments via an onchain vote.

The proposal includes a 5-day challenge period for voters to voice dissenting opinions regarding a deployment, ensuring their say in the process. If there are no major points of contention during the RFC phase, the deployment will be viewed as approved. The current Uniswap DAO, owned by the timelock address, will retain the right to alter the manager again or regain control via an onchain vote.

The new proposed deployment process involves connecting with either the Foundation, Accountability Committee, a delegate, or adjacent party to initiate a deployment. An RFC is posted for a minimum of 7 days, and if no issues arise, the deployment will be viewed as approved, and a 5-day challenge period will be rolled into the onboarding package snapshot vote. The Accountability Committee will then write the relevant text to the subdomain and confirm that the contracts have been verified and the subdomain has been properly updated.

The onchain proposal needs to include function calls to grant the Accountability Committee write permissions to the subdomains, with the DAO retaining the ability to revoke permission through a governance vote.

1. Balancer V2 liquidity mining will operate in three tiers: Tier 1, Tier 2, and Tier 3.

2. Tier 1 pools will be allocated at the end of the transition period (8 weeks from the start of V2 mining) and include: 80/20 BAL/ETH, dynamic fee; 60/40 ETH/DAI, dynamic fee; 50/50 ETH/WBTC, dynamic fee; DAI/USDC/USDT stable pool.

3. Tier 2 and Tier 3 Liquidity Mining Pools will be discussed weekly according to community input and voted on by the Ballers Committee, an open group of active and engaged individuals in the Balancer community who have contributed significantly to the protocol.

4. The goal of using the Baller's Committee is to provide quick responses according to market conditions and avoid extensive overhead on BAL governance.

5. Decisions made by the Ballers will be made public on Balancerâs forum shortly after the end of their weekly meetings, and highly respected individuals and working groups in the space may also be invited to these meetings for strategic input.

6. The Ballers Committee is expected to expand and rotate over time, encouraging regular community members to engage so they can eventually become Ballers themselves.

7. The drawbacks of this structure include potential centralization risks, collusion, and eliminating liquidity incentives for the long-tail of pools. However, it's noted that becoming a Baller requires significant dedication to the protocol, making them highly aligned with the success of Balancer.

8. The transition from V1 to V2 will take place over an 8-week period, with the weekly BAL distribution remaining constant at 145,000 BAL per week spread across both Balancer V1 and V2 during this time.

The Avalanche Foundation has proposed the deployment of the Aave Protocol into the Avalanche network. This is a signal for the Aave community to vote on the acceptance of this deployment. The Avalanche blockchain offers scalability, high throughput, and near-instant finality, making it suitable for DeFi applications. To encourage adoption, the Avalanche Foundation has allocated up to $20M AVAX for users of the Aave protocol over a three-month period as part of their Rush program. The deployment will be subject to a Snapshot vote, and if accepted, initial assets and configurations will be validated. The proposed assets include WAVAX, WETH, WBTC, AAVE, DAI, USDT, and USDC with specific LTVs, liquidation thresholds, and other parameters for each asset.

Title: Adopting Mandatory MEV-Boost for Lido: A Proposal for Decentralized Block Building

Abstract: This proposal aims to enhance the decentralization and scalability of Lido by adopting mandatory use of MEV-boost middleware for all Lido Nodes (NOs). By sourcing blocks from an open, competitive market, we can maximize revenue for Lido, protect Ethereum, minimize MEV hiding, and reduce Lido's power over block production.

1. Adoption of MEV-Boost: All Lido NOs will be required to adopt the MEV-boost middleware to access the distributed block builder market. This market provides an objective source for block templates that maximizes revenue for Lido and minimizes MEV hiding.

2. Monitoring Compliance: Non-compliant NOs can be identified by comparing their produced blocks with the most valuable known block template offered on MEV-boost (the reference block). If there is a significant deviation, the NO was either not using MEV-boost or engaging in MEV hiding.

3. Punishment for Non-Compliance: Lido can punish gross misbehavior by cutting off non-compliant NOs from receiving more stake from the DAO before withdrawals and off-boarding them after withdrawals via an on-chain vote.

4. Choice of Relays: To maintain competition, Lido should enforce both a must-include list (standard relays that all NOs must include) and a must-ban list (for adversarial relays that no NO can include). These lists can be subject to periodic review by the DAO.

5. Policy Maintenance: Lido should use the most decentralized and competitive implementation of PBS, with the goal of using protocol-enshrined PBS in the future. The policy should be reviewed periodically to ensure it remains on the best solution, with reviews happening at least once a year and increasing in frequency as the block template market ossifies.

References:
- Ethereum MEV Extraction and Rewards - Discussion & Policy Groundwork (Izzy)
- Why run mev-boost? (Hasu and Stephane Gosselin)
- mev-boost Github
- MEVâ¦ wat do? (Phil Daian)
- The Risks of LSD (Danny Ryan)
- Should Lido on Ethereum be limited to some fixed % of stake?
- LDO+stETH dual governance (Sam Kozin, Hasu, et al)

In March 2022, they launched BlastAPI.io, providing custom RPC and WSS endpoints for Astar, Shiden, and Shibuya. The infrastructure is geo-load balanced across three regions: North America, Europe, and the Asia Pacific. They are also running collators for Shiden/Astar and Shibuya.

Future plans include releasing a public API feature on Blast and offering support to builders running subgraphs on Astar. They will provide node support to Subscan and BlockScout explorers. Bware Labs focuses on two main directions: API Services and Blockchain Validators, supporting various blockchain projects including those based on Tendermint, Polygon, Elrond, Avalanche, Casper, Moonbeam, Astar, and others. Their API Platform, BLAST, is already live at blastapi.io. They hope for support in their application to join the dApp Staking Program.

The program offers triple rewards: from $LDO token growth, lender interest, and rewards from the program itself. The text discusses a potential expansion of Dai Savings Rate (DSR) options for Dai holders. Currently, there is only one option: instant access at a fixed rate. The poll asks whether offering additional DSR options would be attractive to Dai holders and if notice accounts better align with Dai's investment options.

1. The community has the responsibility to ensure that Strategic Partners (SPs) receiving funding from the treasury are acting in the best interest of the Balancer ecosystem.
2. Any community member can raise concerns if they feel an SP is no longer acting in the best interest, and the Foundation as the DAO's agent must honor the outcome of any legitimate snapshot vote, subject to applicable laws and regulations.
3. The Contribution Funding Pathways outline how funds are distributed to SPs.
4. A delegate system is being created to facilitate transparent and productive dialogue between proposers and large veBAL holders.
5. Delegates and token holders should not vote in favor of or against funding a SP they are affiliated with, and SPs should not offer monetary incentives for votes.
6. A new "Abstain" voting option will be added to Snapshot for cases where an SP is affiliated with many large veBAL holders, preventing them from passing a proposal due to conflict of interest.
7. Risks associated with this system include conflicts of interest, non-compliance by SPs, and unsustainable burn rates. These risks can be mitigated through active community engagement, declaration of conflicts of interest, lower funding requests, milestone-based payments, and open discussions about the impact of funding on the treasury.
8. The proposal will lead to a new tracking system called Balancer Improvement Proposal (BIP), and the Ops subDAO will dissolve at the end of the second quarter, with any remaining funds returned to the DAO Multisig. All powers held by Ops will return to veBAL governance.
9. Future funding proposals must adhere to the guidelines as described above, and an example template can be found here: [example template](https://forum.balancer.fi/t/how-to-create-a-funding-proposal/3233).

In summary, the FEI governance decided not to honor its debt, which would have potentially enabled a risk-free arbitrage with ETH as collateral. Liquidity is crucial in DeFi, and it doesn't necessarily have to be idle cash. Banks have faced liquidity issues since their inception, and the balance between reserves and loans generating profit is delicate.

The Tether case shows that even highly liquid assets can experience drops during systemic shocks, although a serious shock in the commercial paper market and a USDT bank run would be needed to make it a reality. The amount of liquidity buffer needed depends on the stability of deposit accounts or stablecoin holders and the maturity of the rest of the assets. In the real world, 5% cash might not be enough, while in the crypto world, something between 10-20% could be more appropriate due to the faster pace at which things move.

The text provides an update on the Collateral Onboarding (COB) process within the CSI (Collateral Staking Index). It is divided into four sections:

1. Collateral Application Status - Lists all collateral application statuses before prioritization, including those removed from the process.
2. Prioritized Collateral - The "Up Next" status on the new CSI, available for the Collateral Domain Teams to pull in based on several factors.
3. Collateral Work In Progress (WIP) - All collateral in the Assessment through Executive Vote execution as well as any collateral failing a Governance Poll or Executive Vote.
4. Active Collateral - All collateral that is in Business Review status, those that are in Active status and were recently updated, and those collateral that are recently offboarded.

The CSI spreadsheet is the primary source of information for all collateral moving through the COB process. Any discrepancies should be reported to the #collateral-engineering-services-public channel on the official MakerDAO Discord server. For specific questions or comments about collateral, post them in the MakerDAO forum within the collateral application forum post. General questions relating to the CSI update can be posted here.

The text also provides links to view raw and filtered data on the CSI spreadsheet. These include the Collateral Status Index (CSI) spreadsheet, CSI Prioritization spreadsheet tab, CMOFF Prefiltered View 1, CMON Prefiltered View 2, Active (Onboarded Collateral) Prefiltered View, and On Greenlight Status Prefiltered View. The text also mentions the Collateral Onboarding Framework, which describes the origins of the Prioritization tab in the CSI spreadsheet, but it is included for historical purposes only.

1. Emergency Contacts:
   - Aaron Alderman: @aarontanks (Responsiveness Level: High)
   - Daniel Dizon: @daniel_swell (Responsiveness Level: High)
   - Abishek Kanna: @abishek_swell (Responsiveness Level: High)

2. Monitoring Services:
   - Slashing protection, system monitoring is performed by Swell. No specific monitoring of the core token functionality.

3. Multi-Chain Strategy:
   - Swell plans to expand rswETH to other Layer 2s in the near future via a partnership with Layer Zero.

4. Bridge Mitigations:
   - For now, rswETH is not multi-chain.

5. Token Contract Behavior:
   - No more than one address for the token.
   - Compiler version used is 0.8.16 and SafeMath is utilized.
   - The protocol deals with possible overflows and underflows by using SafeMath library functions.
   - No external code execution during the tokenâs function execution.
   - rswETH has unique functionality that allows token to be minted (ETH deposits) but burn cannot happen with zero value.
   - Future functionality will allow users to deposit LST which will also mint rswETH.
   - The token is burnable.
   - Fallback always reverts.
   - It does not have a fixed supply, anyone can mint rswETH with ETH.
   - rswETH is a repricing token.
   - No fees on transfers, fees are taken during reprice by minting additional rswETH.
   - No transfer hooks or arbitrary delegatecalls.

6. Price Feed Behavior:
   - Currently using Redstone price feed and will have a Chainlink price feed in the near future.
   - Approx daily internal rswETH to ETH conversion based on primary asset basis (not secondary market DEX trading).
   - Price updates posted when approx 0.01% difference is reached.
   - Not applicable for AggregatorV3Interface functions revert when called.
   - Bytecode of the custom price feed matches an audited version (not applicable).

7. Upgradability:
   - Upgradeable via transparent proxy pattern with a 7-day timelock and 4/6 multisig.
   - Core protocol upgrades are managed by DAO with strict controls in place, all changes are audited and go through timelock, multisig, and deployment is compared against audited code on etherscan.
   - Standard OZ upgrade event emitted when the implementation is updated.

8. Conclusion:
   - Swell upholds high standards of security and acts in the best interest of the broader DeFi ecosystem. They welcome feedback from the Compound community and look forward to collaborating closely.

The text discusses a need for protection within the AAVE community, suggesting that administrators should prevent unauthorized access and freeze funds if necessary, especially when innocent users are involved. The proposal aims to enable sUSD as collateral on AAVE V3 on Optimism with a maximum supply of 10 million sUSD. Risk parameters include a 60% max LTV, 75% liquidation threshold, and 5% liquidation penalty. The interest rate curve will be upgraded to that of DAI/TUSD and fixed lending is not enabled.

The motivation behind this proposal is the growth in sUSD market cap and its high collateralization by SNX. Allowing collateral use would promote sUSD liquidity in AAVE markets, contributing to its stability. The risk is low due to similar underlying functions as SNX, fully upgradeable contracts, and deep liquidity pools for sUSD on both L1 and L2.

References suggest significant TVL for sUSD and other synth pools on Curve, which help maintain the sUSD peg through arbitrage mechanisms. The Chainlink sUSD price feed is used for reference.

The text is a request from Simon Chandler to an individual involved with Maker, seeking their insights on the impact of incoming DeFi regulations and the stance of governments and regulators towards DeFi. Specifically, the questions are:

1. What is the expected effect of changing cryptocurrency regulations (such as the European Commission's AML proposals and FATF guidelines) on the DeFi sector?
2. Is there a desire among governments and regulators to foster or restrict DeFi growth?
3. How long will it take for DeFi to have clear guidelines and regulations, and should new services be delayed until these are established? Will some choose to hold off launching new services?

The author is writing an article for Cryptonews.com about this topic.

The text outlines a proposed grant program for the 0xDAO community. If approved, funding will come from the community treasury. The program aims to fund projects, ideas, and events that benefit the 0x protocol and its stakeholders, with a focus on areas like protocol improvements, developer tools, research, Dapps, and community building.

The grant program will develop a structured process for evaluating proposals, track progress, collaborate for maximum impact, and measure outcomes to inform future investments. The operations model is yet to be decided, with options including community-managed, committee-managed, or lead with reviewers.

If approved, the program will run for six months, with regular reporting of progress and metrics. The community treasury is seeded with 2m ZRX (~$4m as of 4/1/2021). Success will be measured objectively through ROI, community engagement, and quality of grant applications, and subjectively through improved sentiment within the community and market positioning.

The author invites feedback and support from the community. A poll has been set up for general support and preference in operations model.

Release v1.14.0 was shipped on November 7th, introducing Multi callee support as the main feature. This release also extended the simulation suite and improved the overall User Interface (UI) of our platform. The name of this release is Museo Nacional Thyssen Bornemisza, a Madrid art gallery.

Multi callee support aims to optimize auction results by developing a 1inch-based callee contract. This feature ensures the selection of the price-optimal alternative and provides redundancy in case of service failure. Users can adjust the selected callee via the UI.

The simulation suite was further hardened and extended, allowing for end-to-end simulations of onboarding a new collateral and liquidating a vault for each supported collateral type. The UI was also adjusted, with improvements to the limits panel during the vault liquidation flow and better number formatting across the entire interface.

This proposal aims to increase the MKR capFactor from cap3 to cap4, raising the limit from $10M to $30M. The rationale is that MKR has consistently exceeded its current adjusted liquidity of $10M for an extended period. MKR contributes valuable liquidity to the Balancer ecosystem and was previously primarily traded on Uniswap.

MKR, a DeFi large cap with a market value of approximately $600M, is integral to MakerDAO, a decentralized credit platform on Ethereum that generates Dai, a stablecoin pegged to USD. Users can lock collateral such as ETH, BAT, or WBTC in a Vault to generate Dai debt and pay a continuous interest (stability fee) upon repayment. The system surplus generated from DAI is used for FLAP auctions to burn MKR.

MKR holders also govern the system and serve as a last line of defense during black swan events, with dilution occurring if collateral value drops significantly. The new whitelisting process for Balancer is outlined in detail here.

SEBA Bank has submitted a proposal to Aave Governance for becoming a "Whitelister" on Aave Arc, a permissioned layer of the DeFi protocol. As a licensed Swiss bank serving professional and institutional clients, SEBA aims to bridge liquidities in Aave Arc while remaining compliant with regulatory obligations. This partnership could potentially benefit the Aave community by attracting institutional investments and increasing TVL (Total Value Locked) and protocol revenues. SEBA Bank, founded in 2018, is a pioneering digital asset bank that offers investment, custody, trading, staking, lending, and borrowing services for both digital and traditional assets. The bank's large institutional client base shows significant interest in DeFi products, making it an ideal candidate to provide a secure platform for bridging liquidities in Aave Arc. Further details can be found on the Aave Governance forum post.

Title: Initial Set of Community Treasury Board Members Proposal (PFP-3)

Abstract: This proposal suggests five members for the inaugural Community Treasury Board, each with diverse backgrounds and skill sets to effectively administer the operations, strategy, and transparency of the funding mechanism.

Rationale: To ensure a successful start for the Community Treasury, a governing body is necessary. The proposed members are selected based on their expertise in areas such as blockchain, startup development, education, and community engagement.

Specification:
- David Gogel (dYdX Foundation) - Expertise in go-to-market strategies, partnerships, and ecosystem growth.
- Pete Kim (Creator of Coinbase Wallet) - Passionate advocate for crypto democratization with deep software development expertise.
- Maggie Love (SheFi) - Founder of an educational program to empower women and non-binary folks in Web3 and AI.
- Ajit Tripathi (Hadron Founders Club) - Experienced in promoting Ethereum and Polygon technologies across various sectors.
- Roc Zacharias (Quickswap) - Steadfast advocate for Polygon and Ethereum with a history of bringing projects to these platforms.

The proposal is currently under discussion on the forum, with the status set as proposed. The Community Treasury Board was established in accordance with PFP-02, and this proposal was made on 2024-04-11. All copyrights are waived under CC0 1.0 Universal.

The Balancer/Beethoven X deployment on Optimism is transitioning from v2 to v3 of Mimic's smart vault architecture for fee processing, similar to previous deployments. Instructions and addresses for the Mimic v3 deployment can be found here. Once v3 is fully operational, permissions of the current v2 smart vault will be revoked. On Optimism, the DAO Multisig contract will interact with the Authorizer contract, granting the role to call withdrawCollectedFees on the ProtocolFeeWithdrawer, which corresponds to the Mimic smart vault contract address.

The text discusses a debate over whether Mars should be colonized before focusing on establishing a permanent human presence on the Moon. Some argue that Mars offers more potential for long-term survival, while others believe the Moon is a more feasible and less risky first step in space exploration.

1. First-party oracles like API3 maintain the base feeds on the respective destination chains, and liquidations occur in the same manner as they do on Venus with a liquidation bonus being paid out to the liquidator without recapturing anything. The fee charged to liquidators is the only means of monetization for API3, who are incentivized to keep the OEV Network up and running for a reliable experience.

2. The 30-second delay on base feeds is risky but prices are updated immediately when it matters most (e.g., during liquidations). In case of network downtime or slow updates by liquidators, Venus would be subject to the same delay as the base feeds. However, the resilient oracle approach with a primary oracle like API3, pivot oracle Redstone, and fallback oracle Chainlink reduces this risk significantly.

3. Prices can't be updated with malicious data as OEV Network only auctions off updates from the oracles that are maintaining the base feeds, and the 'oevproxy' on the respective chain can only be updated with cryptographically signed data from first-party oracles run by data providers themselves.

4. The amount that can be recaptured is dependent on liquidator activity and competition on OEV Network. While complete recovery of lost value cannot be guaranteed, auctions have the potential to maximize retained value through competition among liquidators.

5. Integration for current liquidators is straightforward with additional RPC calls to OEV Network and including the oracle update within their bundle. Guides and example scripts are available for liquidators to build upon.

6. Integration for Venus is simple, requiring only reading a new price feed and using the already written and available adapters for oracles pointed towards Venus' 'oevproxy' for each utilized price feed. API3 will deploy the necessary proxies in collaboration with the Venus Technical Teams.

7. Payments are made directly to the API3 data feed contract called API3Server.sol, and each dApp has a specific proxy (e.g., Venus BTC/USD) with a whitelisted wallet that is allowed to withdraw proceeds attached to their specific proxy on API3Server.sol.

8. The integration is currently only on the BNB-Chain due to its potential for recapturing, but OEV Network isn't limited to any specific chain and works on all current Venus Market deployments. The integration can be extended to other networks once feasibility has been proven on BNB Chain.

Title: COSMIZE: Astar's First Metaverse Project

COSMIZE, a metaverse project by Astar, aims to create a virtual space for unrestricted self-expression. With the global metaverse market projected to grow significantly over the next few years, this project is expected to have high growth potential. COSMIZE will expand the range of expression of Astar's IP and enable existing IP NFTs to be used in the metaverse space or converted to 3D for use as avatars. The team behind COSMIZE boasts high technical skills and past achievements, including recognition as a WEF 2022 Technology Pioneer.

The project is divided into three main worlds: Floating world, Under-water world, and Ground world. The Floating world serves as an event hall for the Astar community, while the Ground world allows users to customize their rooms and place NFTs within them. Limited events will be organized for specific NFT holders.

The project is anticipated to bring in new users from outside the Astar ecosystem, leveraging the different user base of DeFi and GameFi. Preparations are being made to increase the utility of $ASTR and provide places for IP NFTs to be utilized, such as the metaverse. The roadmap includes concept design, SAFT completion, whitepaper release, MVP launch, token issue, and continuous improvement of UX/UI. The team consists of metaverse engineers, 3D engineers, application engineers, back-end engineers, front-end engineers, smart contract engineers, sales & marketing personnel, designers, and backoffice staff.

The focus will be on Uniswap V2 and Balancer, with potential future migration to Uniswap V3. The strategy involves monitoring and adjusting the pools based on performance, and exploring outsourcing for Uniswap V3 management.
